title: Getting Started with Lightning
description: A beginner-friendly guide to installing a Lightning wallet and making your first payments. Learn how to receive and send Lightning payments.

sections.title: What is Lightning Network?
sections.body:
The Lightning Network is Bitcoin's Layer 2 payment protocol that enables instant, low-cost transactions. Think of it as Bitcoin's everyday payment layer - perfect for buying coffee, tipping creators, or sending money to friends.

If you're new to Lightning, check out our Lightning 101 page for a deeper technical explanation. This guide focuses on getting you set up and making your first payment.

sections.title: Why Use Lightning?
sections.body:
Lightning makes Bitcoin practical for everyday use:

• Instant Payments: Transactions settle in seconds, not minutes
• Low Fees: Typically less than a penny per transaction
• Micropayments: Send tiny amounts that wouldn't be practical on-chain
• Privacy: Payments don't broadcast to the entire network
• Global: Works anywhere with an internet connection

Whether you're paying for lunch, supporting a creator, or sending money to family abroad, Lightning makes it fast and affordable.

sections.title: Installing Your First Wallet
sections.body:
The first step is choosing and installing a Lightning wallet. We've curated a list of trusted wallets with direct download links.

**Choosing a Wallet:**

• **Custodial Wallets**: Easy to use, but you don't control your private keys. Good for beginners.
• **Non-Custodial Wallets**: You control your keys, but require more technical knowledge. Better for experienced users.
• **Hybrid Wallets**: Offer both options, giving you flexibility.

Visit our Wallets page to browse options, compare features, and find download links for iOS, Android, and desktop platforms.

sections.title: Understanding Your Wallet
sections.body:
Once you've installed a wallet, take time to understand its features:

**Security Considerations:**

• **Backup Your Wallet**: Most wallets provide a recovery phrase (seed words). Write this down and store it securely. Without it, you'll lose access to your funds.
• **Custodial vs Non-Custodial**: Custodial wallets hold your keys (like a bank). Non-custodial wallets give you full control but require you to manage security.
• **Start Small**: When first learning, only put in what you're comfortable potentially losing.

**Key Features to Look For:**

• Invoice generation (for receiving)
• QR code scanning (for sending)
• Transaction history
• Channel management (for advanced users)
• Backup and recovery options

sections.title: Receiving Lightning Payments
sections.body:
Receiving Lightning payments is straightforward:

**Step 1: Generate an Invoice**

Open your wallet and look for "Receive" or "Request Payment". Enter the amount you want to receive (in Bitcoin or your local currency).

**Step 2: Share Your Invoice**

Your wallet will generate either:
• A QR code you can show someone to scan
• An invoice string (starts with "lnbc") you can copy and share

**Step 3: Wait for Payment**

Once someone pays your invoice, the funds appear in your wallet instantly. Most wallets will notify you when payment is received.

**Tips:**

• Invoices expire after a set time (usually 1 hour)
• Each invoice is for a specific amount - you can't reuse them
• For recurring payments, generate new invoices each time

sections.title: Sending Lightning Payments
sections.body:
Sending Lightning payments is just as easy:

**Method 1: Scan QR Code**

1. Open your wallet's "Send" or "Pay" feature
2. Tap the camera/scan icon
3. Point your camera at the QR code
4. Confirm the amount and recipient
5. Tap "Send"

**Method 2: Paste Invoice**

1. Copy the Lightning invoice (the "lnbc" string)
2. Open your wallet's "Send" feature
3. Paste the invoice
4. Review the details (amount, recipient)
5. Confirm and send

**What Happens Next:**

• The payment processes instantly (usually under 5 seconds)
• You'll see a confirmation in your wallet
• The recipient receives the funds immediately

**Common Issues:**

• "Insufficient balance": You need enough funds in your Lightning balance
• "Invoice expired": Ask the recipient to generate a new invoice
• "Route not found": Sometimes the network can't find a path. Try again or use a different invoice

sections.title: Next Steps
sections.body:
Congratulations! You're now ready to use Lightning Network. Here's what to explore next:

• **Browse Wallets**: Check out our curated list of Lightning wallets with detailed reviews and download links
• **Learn More**: Deep dive into Lightning Network technology with our Lightning 101 guide
• **Join Events**: Attend our workshops to learn about running nodes, channel management, and building Lightning applications
• **Practice**: Start with small amounts to get comfortable with the interface
• **Explore Use Cases**: Try tipping creators, paying merchants, or sending money to friends

Remember: Start small, learn gradually, and always back up your wallet!
